everybody I probably should have chosen
some other surprise well this may sound
a bit strange but I don't remember a
time in my life when I wasn't aware of
mental illness and I mean acutely aware
even when I was a little kid some of my
earliest memories are of being together
with hardcore mental patients and this
is because when I was little my mother
was a psychiatric nurse in ojos Denmark
which is the country's second-largest
city and there was a big mental hospital
there and she was and in the geriatric
ward so she was taking care of patients
who had been ill for I mean decades and
some of them had you know been
hospitalized for that long and they were
pretty much all of them hardcore
paranoid schizophrenics and I loved
these patients really every day I would
go see some of them because my dad
wouldn't pick me up and go when my
mother shift was over and so we'd go and
I you know go up the stairs and you know
look for my favorite patients that would
be really really anxious to see me
because I was the only kid they ever saw
that was this you know three four year
old kid and their families never came to
see them basically so some of these
patients were really really nice to me I
remember one who would make stuffed
animals for me in therapy um very
strange ones like I remember an elephant
with very very long legs and made out of
red and white checkered cloth which I
loved
definitely and I was very fascinated
with these people because they were
certainly strange in
anyways and I would you know we would
talk at the dinner conversation at home
would be about so how was my mother's
day and yeah it had been fine
you know this patient had thrown a knife
at somebody and had to be restrained but
otherwise it was all good and I was like
I would sit there with big eyes and you
know why why are they like this why they
like this well because they have a
different view of reality in fact you
know they often hear voices that will
tell them to do these things and I
remember that really intrigued me to the
point where I would sometimes get in the

the door and just sit there and try
really try to hear voices I mean I could
I could I just hear something I never
succeeded but soon after I realized that
mental illness was not just something
that other people had it was not
something that just people in hospitals
had in fact it was rampant in my own
family I remember the first time I went
to see an aunt of mine at the same very
same hospital in a different Ward and
she was in there to have a course of
electroshock treatments so she would be
in there for severe depression and we
would go see her and she would sit there
normally a very talkative lady that was
suddenly completely silent and just
looked very odd and grey and I thought
well you know schizophrenia apparently
people hear voices and depression must
be a disease that makes very talkative
people shut up
it's odd well it was a little more
serious than that
I soon found out because the story of my
grandmother my mother's mother turned
out that she had been severely depressed
in the 50s she was hospitalized for a
year she didn't get out of bed in the
end they wanted to give her a lobotomy
and she was only Saved by the Bell
you know a family doctor saying don't do
this don't do this
and it turned out when I talked a little
bit more to my mother about this well
her father so my mother's grandfather
and in fact shot himself over severe
depression gone out into the barn and
just shot himself and it was it turned
out just mental illness in the family
wasn't just something of the past I
think I was about in my teens when my
father who had a lot of uncles and aunts
suddenly one of these uncle's went out
into the woods where he lived and hung
himself because of depression and it
took another couple of years and an aunt
actually she lived in the country she
went out one day very depressed and
drowned herself in the great big tank
where they keep the pig [ __ ]
and that really to me that brought home
that you know depression is not just any
old disease it's a really really
devastating miserable awful thing and it
got even closer to home when a few years
later when I was growing up my father
was suddenly diagnosed with bipolar
disease and also you know very prone to
depressions now then now all this would
be what a psychiatrist would call a very
interesting family history and I must
admit that that growing up I always have
that feeling of I wonder if this curse
is also going to hit me I mean it's can
I even can I even avoid this at all
and well not surprisingly I did develop

of battled you know manageable
depressions bouts of depressions that
can be treated with
and so on so that's all well and good

well I end up having electroshock

Christ's sake and then a few years ago

personal genomics suddenly became a

and at this point I'm you know I'm a

we can all get genetic information
something that was really just totally
intangible and unrealistic for the

why not make it a really you know

they don't do genes for mental illness

extraversion for example neuroticism
openness agreeableness and
conscientiousness so the first thing I
get into see a psychologist who has

looks at me sort of weird and says are
so you Lona yeah I am I'd like to you

just have to say first that I was

so already that doesn't you know point

and so okay I said well let's get the

the next one oh you have two copies of

sort of you know like I feel like a

have to write this book and I start

well wait a minute
you get this information you get this
knowledge that you have this probably
fairly strong you know predisposition
biological predisposition to this
disease that you've seen and you've seen
the results of it
but what does that mean it doesn't mean

your future is definitely you know deep
depression because now you have you know
this knowledge and what you can start
you can start thinking the thinking
differently and what with what I know

and you change your brain by thinking
and the way you think affect your brain
chemistry and the cells in there and
everything that happens and so I come to
the result really that wait a minute
knowing just knowing that there is this
much biology to the bad news and the
depression in itself creates a sort of
distance so when I come to that moment
when I'm sort of sliding down towards
that you know gray puddle that is

to say it actually works it is the best

and sometimes thinking what would have

would it have what they've been less
miserable would it would it had saved
their lives
because I really really deeply feel for

the more I can control my moods the more
